I grew up in Chicago and people had Pachinko machines in their own homes - at least the people that my family knew, who were The Outfit, so I suppose they were used for gambling. But us kids would play them for hours, until the adults got tired of the noise! When our family went to Vegas when I was around 9 years old I saw an entire section of the casino filled with Pachinko machines, and I played them while my parents were off playing the slots - and no one at the casino stopped me. I loved it, and got hooked! Soon I'll be moving to Vegas, and am looking forward to playing Pachinko again - though sadly it's only found in a few casinos there now.

The Japanese have ways of curbing their urges & tendencies. Same as when joining a biker gangs when you are in your young adult years. But, as expected by society, getting it out of your system & going straight by your late twenties. Or, going big on festivals & letting off because daily life is so rigid. Or, how their music keeps telling young people to be kind, forgiving & to believe in people. This form of gambling "lite" fills the niche of hard gambling that's seen as destructive & legislated as illegal.  Japanese society, as a whole, have a very vague understanding of these self-regulation, but don't ever seem to put it into words. Same as the French, they find it very complicated to put it into words & your just expected to comprehend it -- "makes sense?". Sorta like taboos that are not spoken, but there are nothing wrong with these self-regulations.  When society stresses itself a lot & work hard with much discipline, quirks & urges crop up (such as gambling because of office pressure). Unless the society falls apart, they find ways to let off. Like how Germans are very strict, but when the  company goes out for a drink or when it's Oktoberfest, they really let off.

I have a working 1948 "No More War"  pachinko machine. In getting it working I found out about their history on a Pachinko forum. Post WWII the Japanese people needed lots of aid, but wouldnt accept it from Americans. So the US government opened some parlors with these machines which include some pretty blatant propaganda. The trick was the "Dumb American" running the parlors thought that the machines should be reset after each player opening all the flowers. In this way they were able to give away the food aid in a way that the public would accept.

So, how do particular establishments tell their pachinko balls apart from that of other establishments or forgeries? It looks like just a normal unlabeled metal ball. Couldn't you just buy a ton of them cheaper elsewhere than what the establishment sells them for and turn them in like you won?

Â @sonniepronounceds-au-ni9287Â  In the old days, pachinko parlors required you to borrow balls from the counter, but modern pachinko parlors have machines called "sandos" next to the machines, which dispense loaner balls when you insert cash. The number of balls is recorded, and if the number of balls inserted into the pachinko machine is greater than the number of balls borrowed, a computer in the back room will sound an alarm and a store employee will rush to your aid. In the worst case scenario, the police will show up and you could be arrested.

Living in Los Angeles when I was about 12, probably 1975, my mom and dad bought a lever operated pachinko machine for me and my brothers and sister to play with. We had LOTS of board games and played with them often. But pachinko was a serious departure from our typical games so we all kind of scratched our heads why they had purchased this â€¦ thing. We didnâ€™t have lots of money either so it seems rather frivolous in hindsight. Anyway, it was easily the least played toy we ever got. Thereâ€™s no real skill to it or strategy behind playing it. Plus itâ€™s a solo endeavor so yeah â€¦ it was quickly relegated to a back room where it sat for years until I sold it via eBay about 5 years ago for something like $100.

I feel like Pachinko parlors are in between prize arcades and actual casino gambling. The small pachislot place they were in is more focused on fun and getting prizes while those huge multistory places are ran with the purpose of hooking people to their machines to try their luck for hours at a time. It can certainly be a fun time but I feel that there needs to be a newer type of pachinko that's more skill based for that fun factor to still be there. Gambling is fun in small spurts but getting hooked is obviously terrible. Overall, I have mixed feelings for it but I can't be a hypocrite because I enjoy prize arcades.

Â @killerdustbunny3205Â   Let me explain    His domain is divided in two fases, the initial one where he builds up hype and the events, where he has the chance to hit a jackpot   In the initial fase he can use 3 indicators that the event is coming, the balls, the doors and the multipliers. The balls and doors are divided in four colors (green, red, golden and rainbow), the better the color the higher is the hype, with golden having 80% and rainbow 100% (he can only get rainbow in his forth try)  The hype is the chances of hitting a jackpot during the event (normally the chances are 1/239, but it can increase to even 80%). During the event he calls for a Reach (when a player gets two equal numbers) and hopes for getting the third one, the events are represented by a little movie that plays on the background, if everything in the movie goes right he gets it   Now, in the new chapter we saw the next form of his domain, the Change of Chances. When he hits a jackpot he has two choices for his next domain, he can go to Faster Spins, that makes the events happen faster, or go to the increased probability, where he can activate pseudo-spins, that are rolling just one of the numbers untill he gets what he wants, he basically forces a Jackpot.   Since the Change of Chances has a high chance of Jackpot he can use his third indicator, the multipliers, they build up less hype, but they can somehow rewind time (we see Kashimo defeating him two times, but he breaks the â€œglassâ€ and go back unharmed)

Somebody tried importing second-hand pachinko machines (like those seen at the 2:50 mark) to the US around the late 70s/early 80s and the effort bombed miserably.  The machines never included any play instructions in English so potential customers didn't know the point of the game and how to play ("Is it pinball?"  "I think.  I don't know?"), so many of the machines remained on store shelves, gathering dust.  My mother worked in the back stockroom at a store that sold them and the staff HATED them with the passion of 10,000 burning suns:  virtually every box was never packed correctly and the ball bearings would go everywhere.

Redeeming tickets to circumvent gambling laws isn't that outlandish.  Both Britain and US use this technique to enable gambling for children at arcades. A while ago, in both countries, the laws got stricter and they no longer offer cash prizes, but they do still offer prizes, still charge for the games and still market primarily to children between the ages 9 and 14.  I feel it is somewhat less harmful to market your games to adults and give them tickets to redeem. Not harmless, just less harmful.

Pachinko is deeply intertwined with pinball. The earliest "pinball" machines had no flippers - they were straight-up pachinko machines intended for gambling. They got banned in most places in the US in the 1940's because they were gambling machines akin to slot machines. Flippers changed them into obvious games of skill (rather than the much more subtle skill demonstrated in this video), and led to them being legal again.  It's kind of interesting that pachinko is alive and well in Japan, while pinball is nearly dead in the US.

The non money Pachinko places = Dave and Busters in the United States.  You can't win cash but you can turn your points into prizes.  Unfortunately, you have to pay for your booze.

The key features that define gambling is the ability to bet your winnings back into the game and the ability to convert winnings back into cash.   What I really like about Chuck E Cheeses is that when you buy tokens and play a game, you earn tickets, which can be redeemed for prizes but not cash or more tokens.  This means players cannot earn monetary gains from games or put their earned tickets at stake.

It's so amusing to see Natsuki's different "personalities" - so to speak - between him speaking English and him speaking Japanese. My Japanese language skills are probably about as decent as Natsuki's English language skills, and I've noticed that I end up doing the same when speaking Japanese vs English. It's so funny how you almost become a different person when learning a new language (within the use of that new language). It shines a light on how intrinsically tied to language is to the culture it belongs to. I find it so odd that I didn't pick up on this growing up; my grandparents were bilingual (French - different Canadian dialects - was their first language and then American English). Lol!

My grandma has an old pachinko machine in her basement, so I've played a lot of the super mechanical version of pachinko. Because it was just at a house, there wasn't even a back to hide the mechanics, and watching those machines work from behind is very interesting.
omoroi

When you speak a different language from your own, your mouth moves in a different way, your tongue as well and it goes into different positions. I'm quite sure you use different muscles too, depending on the peculiar sounds you might need to make and that might not exist in your language. When I learned this it blew my mind. So yeah each language is deeply tied to the culture it represents, after all you'd have no culture without a language.

It is caused by how different languages have different gramatic structures, and that requires your thoughts to go through slightly different neural pathways.  But certainly, it is interesting noticing those differences.
I as a native English speaker and being conversant in German, have found Japanese a very edifying language to try to learn. I can almost feel my brain remapping itself and itâ€™s glorious.   Kampai!
Itâ€™s at 621 likes on June 21st

I am a different person when speaking a newly learned language. I don't have the same confidence. I don't have the same experience. I don't have the same level of knowledge. When speaking English, I know enough of the language to differentiate between slang and proper grammar. I can also hear region differences or dialects in English that I don't hear or understand with a newly learnt language. This all effects my confidence and impacts my ability to give and receive information. I am in essence a different person.

I'm mixed race Japanese-American, though I admit my Japanese isn't too great. I definitely agree. I actually support the theory that language changes the way you think. It's our method of higher thought.   I've noticed when I speak Japanese, I am constantly thinking about my place in society in relation to the person I'm talking to... Because it's very important. In English, that's rarely ever a thought. If you're being more formal or polite, it's for a reason. Not just because they're older than you or something. And even then, English is way more casual compared to Japanese.

If what I read many years ago is true, this is not having the coupon redeemed in another building that makes it legal. What happens is that the coupon is a kind of certificate of how many balls you own. Then you go to the different building and "sell them your share", basically saying that the balls are entrusted to the pachinko place. Then, the company that bought your balls sells them back to the pachinko for convenience, since they already hold the balls for you anyway. This way, there is no cash transaction between the pachinko and you so it is not gambling. I don't know if it's accurate, I think I read that in a magazine a long time ago.

The house always wins, right? Even if some pros like Natsuki manage to double the original input, the store can easily double the price of their goods to make sure they don't lose their Yen. As for the balls being 1Â¥ instead of 4Â¥, that doesn't matter for the percentages. I would argue that it even can be detrimental, because all gamblers care about is the constant rattling of incoming bearings, which are only worth 25% of their usual value, forgetting in due time how much weight they put in to begin with. In other words, it might make it easier for them to feel like they're winning while they're not. tl;dr I'm a cynic.

The idea about the ticket being exchanged in a different building somehow making it legal is wrong. It's just a commonly held myth. SO commonly held that when I was in Japan I read an article about how the police responsible for enforcing gambling laws did not know that Pachinko was illegal. But it is, and it is even if you do the ticket swap. It's become simply an unenforced law.

Â @User-1939t9Â  You're still losing a bunch of money on average wherever you go. The house always wins.

Â @foarfieldÂ  I think in this case it is a slow burn rather than an all at once type of thing. At an American casino your betting "unit" is usually at least a $1. In this it is like 3 cents, and it looks like there is more opportunity to win something back. So while at a casino you can have swings of 100's of dollars, in this it is more like swings of 10's, making it much easier to play long term. Plus the parlors are fully aware you can't bleed the customer dry all in one go or even over a few days, they want to encourage you to play regularly, where as a Casino is meant to be more of a vacation/one time thing.

Although their service is great, unfortunately almost of Japanese wish Pachinko disappear. One reason is they own too many stores in contrast to number of their customers. And they are located in very accessible places such as close to the train station and are very vast. The total area of pachinko parlors nationwide will be large enough to make about 10,000 soccer fields. There are about 10,000 pachinko parlors in Japan. This is too much for leisure facilities. Since there are 4,000 amusement arcades and 2,000 karaoke stores, it is clear that the number of stores is abnormal compared to these.And it is said that the number of pachinko users is about 10 million a year. However, this statistic includes the population who has used it only once a year. The average annual number of users per store is 1000 at most. There are only a few thousand people in a store per year. To put it more clearly, only two or three people use it a day. The average number of units installed per store is 66, so you can see how huge this number is. However, pachinko parlors spend an average of about 20 million dollars per user per store, and their sales are 35 thousand dollars, which means that at least 16,5thousand dollars per person is reduced. The average annual income of Japanese is about 44thousand dollars, so you can see how big a loss this is. Of course, there is a return, so not everyone is in such an unfortunate situation, but pachinko is a natural play to lose. Who needs 10,000 such facilities? Many Japanese prefer instead to build meaningful facilities such as parks and nurseries.

its actually simple why japanese people like pachinko. after world war 2, the country was traumatized and the citizens turned to games and amusements to help take their minds off things. simple things like seeing balls roll down and more balls coming out were a therapeutic experience for many. obviously what has happened is this became a national past time and ingrained in the culture. its why arcades still exist in japan today.

It isn't that complicated really. From my understanding: You buy balls with money. You shoot the balls in the game and hope to land them into slots that will award you more balls. Balls can be exchanged for prices. There can be a mini-game in some machines which trigger when you land a ball on specific slot, and you are rewarded more balls if you beat said mini-game (eg. mash a button fast enough to fill a meter like the one in this video).   Feel free to correct me if I'm wrong but it's not any more complicated than this.

The basic nature of gamblingâ€”winning money at the expense of othersâ€”is at odds with the Bibleâ€™s warning to â€œguard against every sort of greed.â€ (Luke 12:15) Gambling is, in fact, fueled by greed. Gaming institutions advertise big jackpots, while downplaying the poor odds of winning, because they know that dreams of wealth prompt players to wager large amounts at the casinos. Rather than helping a person guard against greed, gambling promotes the desire for easy money.  Gambling is based on an inherently selfish goal: winning money that other players have lost. However, the Bible encourages a person to â€œkeep seeking, not his own advantage, but that of the other person.â€ (1 Corinthians 10:24) And one of the Ten Commandments states: â€œYou must not desire . . . anything that belongs to your fellow man.â€ (Exodus 20:17) When a gambler sets his heart on winning, he is, in essence, hoping that others will lose their money in order for him to profit.

Â @lusq600Â  believe it or not it's one of the most philosophically profound anime ever made, but you have to read these 3 "guidebook" things released alongside the 12 episode TV show in order to truly understand it. since 99% of people don't do that, 99% of people only get a superficial understanding of it. (the music and visuals are way above average too so it's still good even if you don't fully understand the hidden messages)

Â @FarvadudeÂ  ...I don't think it's impenetrable. I mean, it takes an understanding of literary code, and some knowledge of Buddhism, but... If you've got that, I don't think it's too hard to pick up the important themes  and metaphors. In about Christmas 1978, my local pharmacy got in a shipment of used, but refurbed pachinko machines, and I got one for Christmas.  (Wish I still had it!).  It was similar to the non-electronic ones shown in this.  A little known fact, the "flipper" that shoots the balls into play has a spring.  That spring is connected to a metal bracket with several holes in it.  So, if you have a machine that people seem to have "figured out", you just move the spring to a different hole, and BOOM.

I played a vintage pachinko machine at a friend's house about 15 or so years ago (his dad had one for some reason, it was basically an antique) and it was a basic pinball-like experience with the mechanical lever to launch the balls like one of the earlier machines in this video.   When I went to Japan recently, I was like "oh yeah, pachinko! I've played that, let's see what it's like in Japan nowadays" and holy god what a fever dream nightmare it has become.  It's gone from an endearing simple Plinko Pinball to an unbelievably loud epilepsy fit of flashing lights with a video game going on in a TV screen that makes absolutely no sense.  I played a Biohazard one (Resident Evil's name in Japan) and it kept doing some kind of slot machine thing with numbers and then a monster would come out and I was supposed to tap a button or something but everything was in Japanese and I couldn't figure out what I was supposed to do.   Even if I had found I was good and could always come out on top winnings-wise I still don't think I could stand going into those parlors because of the obscene noise and smoke clouds from the chain smokers that frequent them.   If anyone knows of a place in Japan that only runs the vintage machines that are quieter, let me know as I really don't care to play the modern ones ever again.

That's also why you have to press A to stop the reels on the slot machines.  Japanese slots have a button under each reel, unlike western slots or fruit machines where the reels stop on their own.  The stop buttons make the slot machine technically a skill game and not a chance game, therefore legal, at least in theory.  The reality is that the reels stop in a random position and have computer-controlled odds and you don't have actual control over the outcome.
Â @andrewsinclair7159Â  American slots have that as well, or they used to

the payout is limited, there is a sbowball/progressive jackpot at each machine, so winning is limited to what that machine have. they sometime wait/mark machines with the biggest loser (jackpot is higher). balls are pretty much standard size, why would you want to bring out the balls? just give to the keeper to count and get the voucher, easy. the 1 yen ball is kinda special, for fun, so it will not use standard ball

there is no guarantee 20% win, its all luck because the ball fall randomly thus considered fair although the nails placement really limit where the ball will fall. out of 100, you might even get 0 falling into the slot. about the merchandise, its usually groceries, the items cost are even lower price than sold, so the house already made some saving there :) dont expect to get rich, usually its just "won 2 pack of cigarettes" sort of thing. in the video, theres a guy who have thousands behobd him, that one probably his only job and i think he aim high.

Â @NEINFUTURERÂ  I find this useful thus is translating it the best I can. "Its illegal to change the size of the ball, thus the ball size is standardised. But the stores do carefully keep in tabs of the total amount of balls on a daily basis. Even a single ball difference would be an issue when the ball stocks are counted, even a mere increase of 50 balls is enough to warrant a problem worth investigating. Even though its hard to catch someone red-handed at their first attempt, the store would have notice something is wrong when its closed. Small stores would have staffs watching over players while bigger stores will have markings on their balls. Even though there won't be any over the top apprehending or arrest happening when a store know there's something wrong, hundreds of CCTV in the store would have took pictures of the offender and shared it with stores around the area and within its own chain store. Little would risk all this to cheat."

Pachinko, oddly enough, was kind of popular here (America) in the mid to late 70s for a short while. I remember getting a Pachinko machine, if you will, from Toys 'R' Us sometime in 1979, maybe even 1980. That didn't last long but I remember it a bit.  EDIT: I was just reminded by my wife that Pachinko became popular here in the U.S. in the late 70s and 80s because of the TV game show, The Price Is Right, where one of the games was called Plinko and worked like a Pachinko game. 1979 Okinawa Japan, Kadian Air force base. I was station there working on F-4Ds. I and four of my Air Force buddies were walking around the red light district called Gate two street. We were frying on some really great LSD and wandered into a Pichinco Palore. We did not know what this thing was. But the noise and people really got use going.  Between the four of us, we won a considerable amount of tickets. Which was the way they paid out in the old days? We followed this guy around the corner to cash it out winnings and it kind of started going sideways because of the amounts. Three of the four of our party we black belts in various forms of martial arts. Once the ass-kicking were done with, our side being the winners. We got a sit down with the Japanese Mafia who ran the games. That started an interesting part of our lives. LSD and good Weed was easy to produce for them. They loved us and all of us made more money than we could have hoped to as Military personnel.

My sister in law drags me out to the local pachi parlor every chance she can get.  I don't play It doesn't really appeal to me but man is she addicted.  I'm ok with goin because there usual a lobby that's sectioned off away from the games that is way less noisy. Comfy enough couches TV plenty of vending machines.  If i'm not there I sit next to her and just watch her play... kinda pointless but still get to see some of the animations.  The noise don't bother me and I haven't seen a place that dosn't allow smoking. In fact most machines have ashtrays and cup holders designed into them and a pull out plastic screen for courtesy if you smoke.  What gets me are the one with all them buttons and flashing lights that say hit now or smash button as fast as you can ect ... they all do exactly nothing, none of them do anything what so ever for game play.   It Is just a gimmick,  kinda like fidget spinners for ADD.  I should also mention tho is there usually open till the early am hours if not all night.  It Is good place to get out of the cold in the winter or into ac in the summer.  Kinda like having to spend a night at a karaoke joint if you ever miss the last train or buss.

Johnny Sack itâ€™s not bullshit. What that commenter is referring to is â€œSunk Cost Fallacyâ€, which is a real thing. Letâ€™s say the addiction starts when someone wins a substantial amount. The idea is that even if they blow all of their winnings, theyâ€™ll still keep playing, because they falsely believe there has to be a payoff to their investment, while in reality itâ€™s all just random.

Johnny Sack it doesnâ€™t just apply to gambling, another example is if you paid for a movie, realized it was total shit a third of the way through, but still sat through the rest of it instead of walking out of the theater because you think youâ€™d have wasted your money if you didnâ€™t finish it, even though youâ€™ve already wasted your money by buying a ticket to a bad movie.

After 10 long years of wishing, I finally started a 3 week vacation about 2 weeks ago in Tokyo (traveling around with the JR pass), and I noticed these places around or near all the major (and sometimes not so major) train stations. I entered one and was immediately confused; it looked like a casino; one that, on the contrary to what we have in the Netherlands, was really easy to access. I was bewildered and confused by all the noise, both digital and of metal ball bearings, and noticed the cigarette smell almost right after. It was too much to take in so I looked around a little and decided it wasn't an arcade or something, so I left again. This video gave me a lot of insight on these places, and if it really only costs 500 yen to buy in, I might try it before I return home (which I really don't want to haha). Currently still in Tokyo until Friday.. I'll definitely return next year for a 4 week vacation instead of 3!  Also, quality production! Great video, I currently work in the Pachinko industry (and have been for over 10years) as an on-air talent. There are so many things which are "not to be spoken" of when it comes to Pachinko. It is actually illegal for someone working in the industry to say how much money they won, so we have to always refer to winnings as the number of balls or coins in the case of Pachislot (Pachinko's slot-like sibling). Balls are rented for 4yen or 1yen, but only have a value closer to 80-90% of that when you want to give them back. This is called the æ›é‡‘ã‚®ãƒ£ãƒƒãƒ— KANKIN GAP, and is where alot of Pachinko parlors make their money. 1yen pachinko tends to have a bigger gap, so despite being more accessible to play due to being cheaper it is actually harder to get your stake back.  I used to work at one of the biggest Pachinko TV program companies till 2017, now I do my own videos on YouTube and stream my Pachinko adventues on Twitch as well. I am famous for being the person to lose the most money in one day on TV, that was 172,500yen. The most I've won is 16,000 coins, each coin is rented for 20yen...  If you want to know more, and even gain permission to film in a larger Pachinko parlor, and perhaps open up the Pachinko world to the West more, I'd be more than happy to help.

Things in general are a bit cheaper, but compared to the huge wins that are "possible" at casinos in America or other countries around the world, Japan's slot and pachinko wins are alot smaller.

Many parlors have 1yen and 4yen areas, which have sensors on either end of the aisles. In some cases they have different coloured balls to help distinguish between 1 and 4 yen balls. I don't know what Matt's on about, but if you can get one of those "weekend of classes, month of online" TEFL qualifications behind you, come in mid-May, and aren't a complete moron, you can pretty much walk into an ALT job, assisting English teachers in Japanese schools. I am a complete moron and have been offered 4 jobs in 5 interviews, and three of those were pushing the contract across the table before I'd even finished thinking about it. You may have heard of the difficult-to-get-on JET Programme, ALT work is basically the same, but with about half the pay and no support. You can still do alright if you are careful, though. (and look for second jobs on Saturdays and evenings at "Eikaiwa", small private schools which are literally everywhere). The hardest parts are banking, housing and local government stuff (the pension system etc), but in cities and big offices there'll probably be an English speaker in there somewhere. Leo Palace readily rent flats to foreigners, they're overpriced for what you get, but depending on where you come from can still seem incredibly cheap. Their English website is full of lies, though. The "ticket system" for pre-purchasing rent on any Leo Palace in the country is complete fiction. It doesn't exist and none of their staff have ever heard about it.

While your video (made from the view point of a complete novice) was excellent you left some things out.  I am an American and I have lived in Japan for about 13 years.  I play pachinko regularly, at least 3-4 times a week.  You missed a few items, first it's not a ticket that you exchange for money.  You take the ticket to the front counter and exchange it for a gift. You can chose an actual luxury item like perfume, watches, toys, etc.. But most people opt for the "Collectible chips"  These chips have some item in-cased in color coded plastic (Yellow = 200y Green= 1000Y, Red= 5000Y. )  These are what you trade at an off site booth/window called a "collectibles shop"  This is how they get around the laws.  And it's not about skillfully placing the balls in the slots anymore, the game boards are setup to make it so about 15-20 balls for every 250 hit the start hole.  To be a true professional you need to be something of a math wizard.  Every game has a stat counter above it.  This display has everything from averages to the amount of start per win etc... You need to understand the average of the game you are playing and the parlors history of payouts.  With this info you can make an educated guess on which machine is going to be set at a higher payout percentage.  It took me years to get fairly good at picking machines but I still lose more then I win.  And the true pros play Pachi-slots not pachinko.  Pachi-slots get pretty complicated with all the stats but, the payouts can be easily 200,000Y+ .

The "ticket" concept is how Indian gambling got a foothold in the United States... the Federal laws stated that you couldn't have cash payouts at the slot machines, so the Indians had 'ticket machines' created to circumvent the rules... well... guess who now uses those same machines (though more sophisticated)?  EVERYONE!  Vegas saw that they could make a LOT more money by using tickets and have since fully converted... sneaky bastids, all of them!

THIS YOUTUBER IS WRONG... I just lived in Japan for the last 3 months and went with my Chinese ex gf multiple times.. I played all day one day.. There is zero skill, it is all chance, and it is stupid.. It is not a 'game' most Japanese will look down at you for wasting your money this way.. it is not a 'game' at all, its just shitty gambling and even slotmachines which are always at the same spot pay out better.. This Youtuber is wrong, you get a small share of gold for your winnings, literally small amounts of gold... and then you 'sell' the gold to the gold exchange across the street.. It is is just sad, I feel bad for all the gambling addicts blowing their money... Most pachinko parlours are filled with cigarette smoke.. This guy is full of crap.. anyone who lived in Japan and got into some weird stuff knows better..

As much as I respect Japanese culture, I will never understand the draw to pachinko.  I guess it's kind of like pinball...  and I love pinball... but pachinko just seems like some kind of ADHD version of pinball combined with cheap slot machine mechanics that addicts people much the same way slots do.  There's just so much random crap going on at one time on a pachinko machine that I think it'd drive me nuts having to sit in one of those parlors for too long.  I dunno...  I guess the draw is kind of like nickel slots in Vegas where you get to play a whole lot for little risk and might win some small jackpot if you play long enough.  I supposed at a price of around one dollar for 100 balls, you're not risking much, but I see videos of Japanese people literally feeding these things thousands of balls at a go and can only think that it can't be a healthy obsession.

Everything in moderation.  Also, 1 yen is 0.009 American dollars... Or 9/10 of a penny.  Even if they are spending 4 yen on a ball, that is 3.6 pennies per ball... Even at thousands of balls I don't see that as terrible.  At one yen it's simply .9 pennies per ball.  I don't see this as being a generally unaffordable hobby/past time. With that said, anyone can make something look bad without moderation.

Well, 100 balls for a dollar was a rough estimation, close enough at 9/10s.  Yeah, the problem is most of the time when you see people playing in these parlors they literally have stacks and stacks of hundreds of thousands of balls they're feeding these things and do so for hours on end.  It's just one of those things that makes the government a lot of money from taxes so they turn a blind eye to it, kind of the same as tobacco, booze, and lottery tickets in much of the US.  A lot of people don't like it, but they ain't gonna say no when it keeps bringing in that so much money.  I'm not saying it should be banned or that it's immoral (though it probably could be in the case of addiction) or any such thing as that... it's just an amusing observation to me, especially when some foreigners like to pretend that Japan is somehow this pristine land that is above such "profligacy".  There's no such petty problems in GLORIOUS NIPPON like in the US.

It's like early pinball, nothing like flipper pinball though. Maybe I'm a bit biased, but it's really not a good comparison at all. Pinball has evolved over the years into a competitive, skill-based game, although it's niche due to arcades falling off in the west. Pachinko has some skill involved with launching the ball, but there's nothing you can do after that outside of what it restricts you to. It's evolved more into a game focused mostly on luck rather then skill, using minigames and a slight element of skill to keep it more interactive then say, slots.

Love the video, but I genuinely feel that portraying pachinko as a "game" is kind of doing more harm than good. Don't get me wrong, I like the way you handled the video, but just like most of Japan's social problems, I think how damaging pachinko machines are to Japanese society gets really downplayed by the government. The entire demographic of these machines is aimed at robbing elderly people of their money through some addictive mindless feedback loop, and I don't think portraying this is as some cool thing to try is really a good idea. Not that I think foreigners are going to come and get hooked on pachinko. That would actually be mildly hilarious. But I really just hate this entire industry as a whole and everything it stands for nowadays.

The need for gambling is readily understood, I think the Japanese have a unique outlook on it as a result of being more accepting of circumstances beyond their control.   A westerner sees little value in a game he does not stand to win. It is only his lesser nature that tempts him into throwing his money away. It is as though he feels that the expenditure of his time and effort does not simply contribute to, but entitles him to victory.   But the Japanese person goes into the experience knowing that most of the balls will whizz  senselessly past their target into the abyss, and for that reason the unexpected victory for which they were never entitled is all the more deserved.  Skinner boxes are only slightly more common in Japanese video games than western, by my estimation at least, but they are presented in ways almost completely contrary to one another.  In western games, chance generally represents realism: the capacity for things to go wrong in unpredictable ways. But in Japanese video games, chance generally represents fantasy: the capacity for things to right in unpredictable ways.  In the west, chance is an obstacle between honest work and success.  In Japan, the obstacle is accepted humbly as a given, and anything bestowed beyond that by chance is a gift.

I have to say Chris, I actually really liked this more history lesson style of video. I'd heard bits and bobs about pachinko and its roundabout form of gambling, but never anything about the history behind it. In fact, learning about Japan's cultural history beyond the broad strokes is rather difficult from the wrong side of the Pacific. If the opportunity arises, I'd love to see more videos like this on your channel, learning more about Japan's modern past from an insider's perspective.  One place I've heard of that I might suggest looking into would be the Meiji Mura Architectural Museum in Inuyama, near Nagoya. This outdoor museum features the largest collection of surviving buildings from the Meiji and Taisho Eras (1867-1926) anywhere in Japan, including the lobby from Tokyo's famous Imperial Hotel designed by Frank Lloyd Wright, and yes, an original Meiji Era sake brewery (don't recall if it's still operational or not).   Also on display are one of the first electric trams to operate in Kyoto, dating from 1912, and a pair of 19th Century steam locomotives, one of which, No. 12, was built in 1874 as No. 23 for the first Kobe-Osaka-Kyoto Railway and is a copy of two of the first steam engines to operate in Japan full stop, on the Shinbashi-Yokohama Line in 1872; these engines, built by Sharp-Stewart of England, were part of an order of 10 such locomotives ordered from 5 different British builders. The Sharp-Stewart engines in particular were considered the most successful of the bunch, so when the time came to order locomotives for the new Kyoto Line, the Railway Ministry went back to Sharp-Stewart and essentially said "Two more of those, please." These survived in government service until 1911, when they were sold to the privately owned Bisai Railway along with a lot of other similar engines from the Shinbashi-Yokohama Line that were also considered too small and old for regular service. Renumbered 12, the engine continued working as a yard shunter, moving wagons and arranging trains, until 1957 when she was finally retired. Thanks to her historical significance she was preserved and first put on display at Meitetsu Line Park until 1963, after which she was moved to Meiji Mura, first being displayed as a static exhibit, but then restored to operation in 1973. She's undergone two major restorations since then, one in 1985 to replace her old boiler, then again in 2010.  Can you tell I'm a history student yet? :P

Holy pachinko Batman, why have I never heard about the Meiji Mura Architectural Museum before!? As an architect and lover of history and historic technology this would be my kind of disney land. Thank you so much for the story.

Glad you enjoyed it, and that I found a kindred spirit in my love for technological and architectural history. Somewhere else you might enjoy is the Edo-Tokyo Open Air Architectural Museum in Koganei Park, Tokyo. This museum features a vast collection of preserved buildings from the Tokugawa/Edo Era, and a few Meiji Era buildings as well, and was one of the sites visited by Hayao Miyazaki when seeking inspiration for his magnum opus Spirited Away. Also on your list should be Ome Railway Park in Ome, Tokyo. Opened in 1962, this is Japan's oldest railway museum, and though small the open air site includes several unique survivors of Japan's age of steam, including another of the original 2-4-0 locomotives from the Shinbashi-Yokohama Line of 1871, this one built by the Yorkshire Engine Co. Finally, for the big ones at least, there's the Historical Village of Hokkaido. Far less well known than Edo-Tokyo or Meiji Mura, this museum in Sapporo nonetheless boasts a comprehensive collection of buildings from the Meiji to Showa Eras that chart Hokkaido's modern history, from traditional houses from farms and fishing villages to larger structures like the old Sapporo Railway Station and Colonization Commission Office, with much of the site being linked by a horse-drawn tram line.  If this still hasn't whetted your appetite, I'm currently researching other sites of interest regarding Japan's Meiji Era and industrial history. I would be happy to share them, if Chris doesn't mind this comment thread getting a bit longer.

The interesting thing i realised from this video: Japanese gambling laws were the reason why the game corner in pokemon had the rewards building seperated from it.  Side information beyond this revelation:  However, even with the work around the law, the european ratings board still decided that it was gambling when they updated their rules in 2010. So even though the japanese didn't consider it gambling, they had to remove the game corner in future games to continue being able to sell the games to the european childrens market, rather than having the games rated 12.

Hilarious game.  A family friend had a smaller version in her house and as kids, my older sisters and I would always want to play. We loved the sound and the lights. It all came to a screeching end when I, as a curious 7 year old, got one of the balls stuck up my nostril.  My mom was so embarrassed she asked her friend to cover the game and not let us play again.  So it sat there every visit, like a ghostly monolith trying to make us disobey our parents by clinking a few balls when we walked by.  They told us the machine was broken but I knew they just didnâ€™t plug it in.  Oddly, I am not drawn to slots, the American equivalent.  Now that slot machines have gone digital I have even less interest without the sound  and tactile quality of dropping coins.  I believe it is because of people like me, they encase pinball games under glass and make the balls significantly bigger. Youâ€™re welcome.
So what is preventing them from legalizing gambling?

The fact that each ball costs about 4 yen reminds me of a video I saw about pay-to-win 'free' games.   Basically, the idea is to give you a weird idea of how much value a ball has, so you can't properly determine how much you're spending while playing with them.   For example: Let's say that a game uses gems, and it takes 51 gems to speed up something in a game. You can buy 164 gems for $5.60. How much would you pay for that upgrade?  Without sitting to do the math, it's impossible to tell.

First you hear it. Then you smell it (the cigarette smoke). And finally, you stumble through a crowded room, disorientated and confused, before leaving subsequently deaf. It's an experience many foreigners in Japan have had, and I was no different. I'll never forget being bewildered by Pachinko when I discovered it 6 years ago. Now for the first time, it's time to actually work out what it is, and why it's so popular. IF YOU'VE PLAYED PACHINKO, share your thoughts on it. Maybe it'll help the rest of us make better sense of it.

It's not so much racism (belief that your race is superior and others are inferior) and more xenophobia (fear or apprehension of people from outside your country).  The word "racism" gets thrown around a lot more than it should, these days.  In my experience with Japanese people, many of them are especially shy or wary of non-Japanese people, but once you get to know them and demonstrate that you have similar values and will respect their culture, they are very warm and welcoming.  When I mention that I have been studying their language, they are immediately eager to talk to me.  Japanese being a difficult language, and foreigners in Japan so often failing to make a concerted effort to learn it, I'm not surprised; I think that probably goes a very long way to explain their apprehensions toward foreigners.

I agree that it becomes more apparent to immigrants than tourists. For example, public servants in tourist heavy places like Tokyo are hardwired to speak english to any westerner. A subway employee will aproach you ask if you need help in english when your eyes even slightly hover over a map. Wich is helpfull and pleasant if youre a tourist. But if youve been living in Japan and been using that subway to get to work every day for a long time I imagine it gets quite tiresome.
